title: Less helpful compiler error upon module/trait name clashes

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I was encouraged [1] to report this and filing as a bug seemed the most appropriate.  The issue is of course clear to the experienced user, but it was very confusing.  The issue is that moving a trait into a module with the same name leads to confusing compiler errors.  It's possible this could be improved by noticing the clash which is bound to lead to problems.  The full repro [2] has not been boiled down as it's simple enough and I wanted to give the context to motivate why I would have done this, however the gist is this:

[1] https://twitter.com/ekuber/status/1393605930483388416
[2] https://github.com/tommythorn/bp/tree/newb-struggles

```rust

```

I expected to see this happen: telling me that what I thought was a trait was now a module

Instead, this happened:
```
  error[E0599]: no function or associated item named `new` found for struct `Boolish::TwoBitCounter` in the current scope
     --> src/main.rs:179:39
      |
  37  |     pub struct TwoBitCounter {
      |     ------------------------ function or associated item `new` not found for this
  ...
  179 |         let pht = vec![TwoBitCounter::new(true); 1 << addr_bits];
      |                                       ^^^ function or associated item not found in `Boolish::TwoBitCounter`
      |
      = help: items from traits can only be used if the trait is in scope
  help: the following trait is implemented but not in scope; perhaps add a `use` for it:
      |
  2   | use crate::Boolish::Boolish;
      |
 ```


```
mod Boolish { // XXX
    pub trait Boolish {
        fn update(&mut self, taken: bool) -> &mut Self;
        fn value(&self) -> bool;
        fn new(b: bool) -> Self;
    }
...
    impl Boolish for TwoBitCounter {
        fn update(&mut self, taken: bool) -> &mut Self {
            ...
        }
...
} // XXX
use Boolish::*; // XXX
...
    fn new(addr_bits: usize) -> LocalBp {
        let pht = vec![TwoBitCounter::new(true); 1 << addr_bits];
```

Without the lines marked with XXXs this works perfectly.

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->
